ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Advanced concepts in condensed matter physics
I had exposure to solid state physics and second quantization of operators.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course covers many advanced topics, so the main criticism I would give would be that it should more clearly state its prerequisites as a course. For really making the best use of this course, one should take 2 graduate courses in quantum mechanics and maybe one introductory course in Solid State physics. In my case I had not taken these courses, and I felt I had important gaps in my knowledge on these previous subjects, which greatly hindered my engagement and learning in this course. I felt that I had to devote huge amounts of time per week in order to be able to finish my homework assignments and keep up with the pace of the class, to the point where it negatively impacted my outcome in other courses this semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend it to anyone who has a prior background of quantum mechanics and wishes to learn advanced condensed matter theory.

Only if the student has the necessary background stated above, and does not have a large workload on the semester he or she plans to take this course. This course requires a great deal of dedication, but the instructor is very helpful and covers a broad range of topics.
